items.title: BBC’s top leaders resign over Trump speech editing controversy
items.standfirst: The BBC’s top officials, Tim Davie and Deborah Turness, stepped down amid allegations a documentary misleadingly edited Trump’s Jan. 6 speech.
items.content: The BBC’s top officials, Tim Davie and Deborah Turness, stepped down amid allegations a documentary misleadingly edited Trump’s Jan. 6 speech.

items.title: ‘I have to take ultimate responsibility’: Tim Davie’s BBC resignation statement
items.standfirst: Full text of director general’s note to staff and the resignation statement from head of news Deborah TurnessDavie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverageBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.This afternoon Davie sent the following note to staff:Dear all,I wanted to let you know that I have decided to leave the BBC after 20 years. This is entirely my decision, and I remain very thankful to the Chair and Board for their unswerving and unanimous support throughout my entire tenure, including during recent days.Dear all,I have never been more proud of the work that you do every day. You really are the best of the best. Continue reading...
items.content: Full text of director general’s note to staff and the resignation statement from head of news Deborah TurnessDavie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverageBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.This afternoon Davie sent the following note to staff:Dear all,I wanted to let you know that I have decided to leave the BBC after 20 years. This is entirely my decision, and I remain very thankful to the Chair and Board for their unswerving and unanimous support throughout my entire tenure, including during recent days.Dear all,I have never been more proud of the work that you do every day. You really are the best of the best. Continue reading...

items.title: Tim Davie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverage
items.standfirst: Davie says departure is ‘my own decision’, while head of news also quits. Insiders say it ‘feels like a coup’ by broadcaster’s enemiesBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In an announcement that caused shock within the corporation, Davie said his departure was “entirely my decision” and it comes as the BBC prepares to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speech. Continue reading...
items.content: Davie says departure is ‘my own decision’, while head of news also quits. Insiders say it ‘feels like a coup’ by broadcaster’s enemiesBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In an announcement that caused shock within the corporation, Davie said his departure was “entirely my decision” and it comes as the BBC prepares to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speech. Continue reading...

items.title: Millions of Americans facing delay after court interrupts SNAP food stamp payments
items.standfirst: The Supreme Court on Friday granted the Trump administration’s emergency appeal to temporarily block a court order to fully fund SNAP food aid payments amid the government shutdown, even though residents in some states already have received the funds. Nicholas Rushworth tells us more.
items.content: The Supreme Court on Friday granted the Trump administration’s emergency appeal to temporarily block a court order to fully fund SNAP food aid payments amid the government shutdown, even though residents in some states already have received the funds. clusters.title: Philippines hit by 'intense' typhoon as nearly a million evacuate
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Fung-wong Hits Philippines, Nearly One Million Evacuated

items.title: Philippines hit by 'intense' typhoon as nearly a million evacuate
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), hit the Philippines as a super typhoon and later weakened.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), hit the Philippines as a super typhoon and later weakened.

items.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
items.standfirst: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...
items.content: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...

items.title: BBC on Luzon Island as super typhoon hits Philippines
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.

items.title: Nearly one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong nears Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.

items.title: As Super Typhoon Fung-wong nears, Philippines on edge
items.standfirst: The storm already kills at least one person, disrupts power and forces evacuations of nearly one million people.
items.content: The storm already kills at least one person, disrupts power and forces evacuations of nearly one million people.

items.title: Philippines evacuates nearly a million as floodwaters rise and super typhoon nears
items.standfirst: The Philippines evacuated hundreds of thousands of people on Sunday as a super typhoon Fung-wong moved west towards the archipelago nation. The storm is set to bring wind and heavy rain to broad swathes of the country just one week after another typhoon, Kalmaegi, killed hundreds of people in the Philippines.
items.content: The Philippines evacuated hundreds of thousands of people on Sunday as a super typhoon Fung-wong moved west towards the archipelago nation. The storm is set to bring wind and heavy rain to broad swathes of the country just one week after another typhoon, Kalmaegi, killed hundreds of people in the Philippines.

items.title: Nearly a million people evacuate as Super Typhoon Fung-wong threatens the Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.(Image credit: Malacanang Presidential Communications Office)

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong hits Philippines - with two dead and one million people evacuated
items.standfirst: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.

ai_summary: Typhoon Fung-wong hit the Philippines with sustained winds of 185 km/h.
Over one million people were evacuated due to the approaching typhoon.
The storm caused at least two deaths and disrupted power in the Philippines.
The typhoon is the second major storm to hit the Philippines in recent days.
The storm is set to bring heavy rain to the archipelago nation.

items.title: Flight cancellations rise as Sean Duffy warns travel will be reduced to a ‘trickle’
items.standfirst: Flight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal…
items.content: Flight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal…

items.title: US flight cancellations rise as Sean Duffy warns travel could reduce to a ‘trickle’
items.standfirst: Over 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persistsFlight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal government shutdown.If the shutdown continues, the FAA has instructed airlines to cut 6% of flights on Tuesday – and to do the same to 10% by 14 November. The transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, has warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the shutdown persists, and on Sunday he predicted a “substantial” number of people in the US would be unable to celebrate the upcoming holidays with their families if the shutdown wasn’t resolved. Continue reading...
items.content: Over 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persistsFlight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal government shutdown.If the shutdown continues, the FAA has instructed airlines to cut 6% of flights on Tuesday – and to do the same to 10% by 14 November. The transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, has warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the shutdown persists, and on Sunday he predicted a “substantial” number of people in the US would be unable to celebrate the upcoming holidays with their families if the shutdown wasn’t resolved. Continue reading...

items.title: US Government shutdown hits 39th day
items.standfirst: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Nearly 6,000 more were delayed, down from 7,000 on Friday, FlightAware reports. The FAA is reducing capacity at 40 busy airports as unpaid, fatigued air traffic controllers work. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.
items.content: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Nearly 6,000 more were delayed, down from 7,000 on Friday, FlightAware reports. The FAA is reducing capacity at 40 busy airports as unpaid, fatigued air traffic controllers work. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.

items.title: More than 1,400 flights cancelled as US air traffic cuts enter second day
items.standfirst: Thousands more flights have been delayed or cancelled as the reduction of air travel capacity continues during the federal government shutdown.
items.content: Thousands more flights have been delayed or cancelled as the reduction of air travel capacity continues during the federal government shutdown.

ai_summary: Flight cancellations have increased due to the ongoing government shutdown.
Over 7,000 flights were delayed on Sunday due to the shutdown.
Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned of reduced air travel.
Duffy stated air travel could be reduced to a "trickle" before Thanksgiving.
Thousands of flights are being canceled as air traffic controllers go unpaid.

items.title: Syrian president al-Sharaa arrives in US for landmark White House visit
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.

items.title: Syria's Sharaa arrives in US for Trump talks after sanctions lifted
items.standfirst: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.
items.content: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.

items.title: Explosives and weapons seized - with 71 arrests - as Syria launches clampdown on Islamic State cells
items.standfirst: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.
items.content: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.

items.title: Syria carries out preemptive raids against Islamic State
items.standfirst: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...
items.content: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US for talks with Trump.
Syria carried out preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells.
71 people were arrested and explosives and weapons were seized.
The visit is the first by a Syrian president since the country's independence.
The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House.

items.content: The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.

items.standfirst: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.
items.content: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.

items.title: Israel receives remains of hostage that Hamas says is IDF soldier killed in 2014
